titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Department of Computer Science Records CA.MS.00130
titlestmt.author: Elisha Winkler

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-06-06 17:21:29 -0400.

change.item: This resource was modified by the ArchivesSpace Preprocessor developed by the Harvard Library (https://github.com/harvard-library/archivesspace-preprocessor)
Containers added and finding aid updated as part of College Archives survey

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Smith College. Dept. of Computer Science.

did.abstract: This collection contains exam questions, newspaper articles, and black and white photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Computer science was first taught for credit at Smith College in 1972 by Bert Mendelson, who was the founder of the program. The Department of Computer Science was established in 1988 by college president Mary Maples Dunn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Computer Science Department records contain materials describing the courses, students, and faculty of the department. Types of materials include a final exam, newspaper articles, and black and white photographs of students and faculty.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Department of Computer Science Records, Smith College Archives, CA-MS-00130, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers should also view: RG 42. Faculty

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Smith College retains copyright of materials created as part of its business operations; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Smith College, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Computer Science Department records were created by the department and tranferred to the College Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Please note that prior to 2018, folder inventories were not always updated when new material was added to the collection. As a result, folder inventories may not be complete and folder numbers may be incorrect.

controlaccess.corpname: Smith College. Dept. of Computer Science.

did.unittitle: Newspaper articles, black and white photos

dao.title: Link to Department of Computer Science website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The website of the Computer Science Department at Smith College (http://cs.smith.edu/) includes information on faculty, courses, the major and minor, news, events, and resources for students.
The website was first captured in 2015. Subsequent captures are scheduled annually.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright to web content created by or for Smith College, is owned by Smith College; however, copyright in third-party content on these websites may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Smith College, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.
